Old people playing video games
Monster Rancher Metropolis: The Cafe: Archived Topics From Prior Years: Year 2000 Topics (Year Of The Phoenix): Old people playing video games
By torey_luvullo on Wednesday, June 7, 2000 - 09:42 am:

just read the newsweek article on "nintendo's racy new games". in it appears a description of the "racy new game" [which basically sounds like a shoot 'em up with some suggestion, rather than actual depiction, of female nudity] and a statistic - 21% of all video game players are over the age of 35. much of the article is devoted to discussion by game company execs about how to capture this burgeoning market.

here's a hint on how they can capture me. in the description of "lara croft with breast reduction" [or whatever its called] they describe a feature where when the character on the screen is hit, the view goes blurry to indicate your wooziness. it got me to thinking. one of the things i like about mr and mr2, which is different from most other games, is that in most games you "are" the character on the screen. in mr and mr2 you "are not" - you "are" yourself, managing characters on the screen in the raising, fighting, and breeding of your stable of monsters.

be interested to hear others' take on this.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Wednesday, June 7, 2000 - 10:21 am:

Well, I'm not over 35, but my SO is close to that, at least. His take on this is to get rid of some of the 'splatter' effects that people go for in hte games nowdays. Everything seems to be built aruond shoot-em-up or combo-your-opponent-to-death. He prefers the skill, rather than the gore. Guns are one thing, but the challenge is in the playing, and not in the 'How many times can I kill people?'.

My outlook is actually vaguely similar to his, though for me, I mostly look for a more in-depth storyline. Or at least in-depth play-value. Pokemon (believe it or not), Monster Rancher (GASP! ME?!), and almost all RPGs are very engaging to me for these reasons. I don't need to see the sword running someone through and blood spatternig for the effect. I just need to know how to progress the storyline, as well as raising my character (or monster) in one way or another.

By phoenix masta on Wednesday, June 7, 2000 - 11:55 am:

Yeah I love stuff that has a good storyline and mental challenge. One exception for me is Tony Hawk Pro Skater. be seein' ya

By Lisa Shock on Wednesday, June 7, 2000 - 12:03 pm:

I enjoy games that have more purpose than, "run & jump & grab all the stars you can find". That's why I like sims, I really enjoy biulding something and seeing how well it turns out. I enjoy puzzle games as well and REALLY wish they'd bring Tetris Attack 64 to the US.

By Argos on Wednesday, June 7, 2000 - 03:29 pm:

I like developing characters,problem solving,puzzles or mysteries. Might and Magic,Romance of the 3 Kingdoms were a couple favorites before MR2.
But I liked some shootem ups,battling games too. Killer Instinct,the Abrams tank game; Turok and Star Fox on 64.

But overall I'd still prefer an RPG to most other game types.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Friday, June 9, 2000 - 08:57 am:

I'm 23, but pregnancy shuold add a couple years onto someone's life. That's gotta be a rule somewhere!

By locke on Friday, June 9, 2000 - 10:47 am:

I have a son who's nearly 21... I think I'm 2nd oldest here :)

By Tony on Friday, June 9, 2000 - 12:08 pm:

I'm 28, and play this and other games as well. I gotta get a break from reallife BS every once in a while, and MR and other games is usually how I do it.
